profile_positions.company: UMCG Medical Microbiology and Infectionprevention - Molecular Bacteriology
profile_positions.description:
Development of greener, more sustainable platforms for high-value recombinant protein production. The project will address the rapidly-emerging issue of 'sustainability' in the European biotechnology industry by focusing on improvements in yield and process design that markedly reduce the high current levels of waste, and by helping to deliver industrial enzymes that reduce energy and raw material costs in countless industrial and domestic settings.

My role in this project is to create overviews for the EU to keep track of the status of the project. On top of this I am also involved in the supervision of the PhD students, applied on this project.
profile_positions.title: EU Project Manager (GreenerRPP)

profile_positions.company: UMCG Medical Microbiology and Infectionprevention - Molecular Bacteriology
profile_positions.description: My research objectives mainly involve improvements in protein secretion of Gram positive bacteria to create insight in the pathways involved in this process. This will create more insight in the possibility to increase the production of industrially or therapeutically used enzymes.
profile_positions.title: Lab manager and Postdoctoral Researcher

company.name: UMCG Medical Microbiology, Dept. Molecular Bacteriology

profile_positions.company: UMCG Medical Microbiology, Dept. Molecular Bacteriology
profile_positions.description:
A tale of two cellfactories - Heterologous proteïn production in Bacillus subtilis and Lactococcus lactis

The research described in my PhD thesis was aimed at the development and optimization of systems for secretory protein production based on two widely used Gram-positive bacterial cell factories, namely Lactococcus lactis and Bacillus subtilis. The primary objective for the studies in L. lactis was to apply this bacterium for production of staphylococcal proteins in order to study their biological function, to profile human antibody responses against these proteins, and to assess their application potential for anti-staphylococcal vaccination. The main objective for the studies in B. subtilis was to compare the impact of various secretion machinery components on extracellular protein production and to apply the obtained insights to enhance the productivity for industrial enzymes.
profile_positions.title: Researcher-PhD fellow

profile_positions.description: Perform clinical tests and setting up new techniques
